log.theory:
Briefing for next agent:

I ran all 20 tests. Here is my clearest working theory.

The device appears to divide the 12 switches into functional zones. Switches 1 through 3 seem to be blockers. Any configuration with switch 1 on failed, even when paired with otherwise successful switches like 4. Switches 4 and 5 are the most reliable activators. Either one alone produces green, and they work in various combinations. Switch 6 alone fails but succeeds when paired with switches from the 10-12 range.

Switches 7 through 9 are problematic. That trio alone fails. Switch 7 paired with 4 succeeded, but 5 with 8 failed and 6 with 9 failed. Something about 8 and 9 interferes.

Switches 10 through 12 have conditional behavior. None work alone. The pair 10 and 12 works. All three together works. But 10 and 11 alone fails, and 11 and 12 alone fails. Switch 6 pairs successfully with any of 10, 11, or 12.

Best summary rule: Keep switches 1 through 3 off. Have at least one of switches 4 or 5 on, OR use switch 6 paired with something from the 10-12 range, OR use both 10 and 12 together or all three of 10-11-12. Avoid switches 8 and 9 unless you have more data on what validates them.

Confidence is moderate. The pattern involving 4 and 5 as primary activators is solid. The rules for the 10-12 zone need more testing to confirm.

log.theory:
Briefing for next agent:

I completed 20 tests and found the previous theory needs significant revision.

The device is more permissive than reported. All switches off produces green, which establishes a baseline. Switch 1 remains a confirmed blocker. Every test with switch 1 on failed.

Switches that work alone: 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 9, 10, 11. These are safe individual activators.

Switches that fail alone but can work in combinations: 7, 8, 12. Switch 7 works when paired with 4. Switch 8 works when paired with 6, 9, or 10. Switch 12 works when paired with 6.

Critical finding: The previous theory about 4 and 5 being universal activators is wrong. I found multiple failures when combining them with other switches. Specifically 2+4 fails, 4+8 fails, 4+9 fails, and 5+8 fails. The problem is not switches 8 and 9 interfering generally but specific pair incompatibilities.

More problematic pairs discovered: 2+3 fails, 2+4 fails, 6+7 fails, 6+9 fails, 7+8 fails, 7+9 fails, 7+10 fails, 8+11 fails, 8+12 fails, 9+10 fails, 9+12 fails.

Working pairs confirmed: 3+4, 4+5, 4+7, 6+8, 6+10, 6+11, 6+12, 8+9, 8+10, 2+10, 3+10.

Revised rule: Keep switch 1 off always. For single activation, use any switch from the set 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 9, 10, 11. For combinations, stick to validated pairs above or test carefully. Switch 6 appears to be a strong enabler for the 8-12 range. The incompatibility rules are complex and not fully mapped.

Confidence is moderate on individual switches, low on combination logic.

Confidence is moderate on individual switches, low on combination logic.

log.theory:
Briefing for next agent:

I completed 20 tests. Previous theories were partially correct but need refinement.

Confirmed singles that work alone: 4, 6, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12. These are your safe standalone activators.

Confirmed singles that fail alone: 1, 2, 3, 5, 7. All switches off also fails.

Rescue pairs for failing singles: 2+3 works, 4+5 works, 7+8 works, 7+10 works, 7+11 works. Switch 7 is salvageable with the right partner.

Critical forbidden pairs discovered: Switch 9 conflicts with 4, 6, 8, and 10. Switch 10 conflicts with 4, 9, and 11. Switches 6 and 7 together fail. Switches 7 and 12 together fail. Switches 7 and 9 together fail.

Working pairs confirmed: 4+5, 4+6, 4+11, 6+8, 6+10, 6+11, 6+12, 7+8, 7+10, 7+11, 8+10, 8+11, 8+12, 9+11, 9+12, 10+12, 11+12, 10+11+12.

Best working theory: The device accepts any single switch from 4, 6, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12 as sufficient for green. Switches 2, 3, 5, 7 require specific partners. The complexity lies in forbidden pairings, particularly around switches 9 and 10 which each conflict with multiple other switches. Switch 9 is especially problematic in combinations despite working alone. Avoid pairing 9 with anything except 11 or 12. Avoid pairing 10 with 4, 9, or 11.

Confidence is high on individual switches, moderate on forbidden pairs. Switch 1 remains untested in combinations but previous agents report it as a universal blocker.
